column1:
Company Z spent 1/4 of its revenues last year on marketing and 1/7 of the remainder on maintenance of its facilities. What fraction of last year’s original revenues did company Z have left after its marketing and maintenance expenditures?
Options:
(A) 5/14
(B) 1/2
(C) 17/28
(D) 9/14
(E) 9/11
column3:
Total revenues = x
Spent on marketing = x/4
Remaining amount = x-x/4 = 3x/4
1/7 of the remainder on maintenance of its facilities = 3x/4*1/7 = 3x/28
Amount left = 3x/4-3x/28 = 9x/14

There are two water tanks A and B, A is much smaller than B. While water fills at the rate of one liter every hour in A, it gets filled up like 10, 20, 40, 80, 160 in tank B. (At the end of first hour, B has 10 liters, second hour it has 20, third hour it has 40 and so on). If tank B is 1/32 filled after 21 hours, what is the total duration required to fill it completely?
Options:
(A) 22
(B) 28
(C) 269
(D) 26
(E) 82
column3: The data related to the first tank A is not necessary. As you can see, the capacity that gets filled in the tank B after each hour is doubled. So If the tank is 1/32nd part is full after 21 hours, it is 1/16th part full after 22 hours, 1/8th part full after 23 hours, 1/4th part full after 24 hours, 1/2 full after 25 hours, completely full after 26 hours.

The average of 13 result is 60. Average of the first 7 of them is 57 and that of the last 7 is 61. Find the 8th result?
Options:
(A) 35
(B) 37
(C) 46
(D) 48
(E) 50
column3:
Sum of all the 13 results = 13 * 60 = 780
Sum of the first 7 of them = 7 * 57 = 399
Sum of the last 7 of them = 7 * 61 = 427
So, the 8th number = 427 + 399 - 780 = 46.

Last year, Company M made q dollars in profit. Half of the profit went to the company’s founder. The rest was split evenly among his Three other partners. In terms of q, how much did each of the other partners receive?
Options:
(A) q/4
(B) q/5
(C) q/6
(D) q/7
(E) q/8
column3:
Profit = q
Profit to company founder = q/2
Profit to other partners = q/2
Number of other partners = 3
Profit to each partner = (q/2)/3 = q/6

The average age of a class of 32 students is 16 yrs. if the teacher's age is also included, the average increases by one year. Find the age of the teacher
Options:
(A) 45 Years
(B) 46 Years
(C) 49 Years
(D) 52 Years
(E) 54 Years
column3:
Total age of students is 32X16 = 512 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 33X (16+1) = 561
So, Teacher's age is 561-512 = 49 Yrs
There is a shortcut for these type of problems
Teacher's age is 16+(33X1) = 49 Years

(B) 6/11
(C) 6/12
(D) 6/10

column3: Part filled by (A + B + C) in 3 minutes = 3(1/30 + 1/20 + 1/10) = 11/20\nPart filled by C in 3 minutes = 3/10\nRequired ratio = 3/10 * 20/11 = 6/11

column1:
Two trains are traveling on parallel tracks in the same direction. The faster train travels at 130 miles per hour, while the slower train travels at 80 miles per hour. At 2 o’clock the faster train is 20 miles behind the slower one. How far apart are the two trains at 5 o'clock?
Options:
(A) 60 miles
(B) 80 miles
(C) 90 miles
(D) 130 miles
(E) 400 miles
column3:
Answer = D. 130 miles
Relational speed = 130 - 80 = 50 miles per hour
In 3 hours, difference = 50 * 3 = 150 miles
Fast train trailing 20 miles, so effective difference = 150 - 20 = 130 miles

(C) 5 hours.
(D) 4 hours.

column3: In one hour, Anmol eats 27 pastries, Aakriti eats 12, and Divya eats 21. A total of 60 pastries. Therefore 180 pastries would take 180 ÷ 60 = 3 hours.

column1:
There are 6561 balls out of them 1 is heavy.Find the min. no. of times the balls have to be weighed for finding out the haevy ball.
Options:
(A) 7
(B) 8
(C) 9
(D) 10
(E) 11
column3: The simple logic is to divide total balls into three sets. Weigh any two sets against each other(these two must contain equal number of balls). From this we can identify which set contains the heavy ball. Divide this set into three and repeat until you find the heavier ball. Under this logic, the minimum number of weighings required turns out to be the smallest integer greater than or equal to log(n), where n is the total number of balls and the base of logarithm is 3. Or simply [log(n)/log(3)] with any base. Here, n = 6561. log 6561 / log 3 = 8

If six persons sit in a row, then the probability that three particular persons are always together is?
Options:
(A) 1/5
(B) 1/4
(C) 1/9
(D) 1/6
(E) 1/1
column3: Six persons can be arranged in a row in 6! ways. Treat the three persons to sit together as one unit then there four persons and they can be arranged in 4! ways. column3: Let the length Q of the rectangle be 100x, and width be 100y. Area = 100x * 100y = 10000xy\nNow after the change Length = 85x, and width = 140 y. Area = 11900xy\n% Change = (11900xy - 10000xy)/(10000xy) = 19 % Increase. Hence

column1:
A person spends 1/3rd of the money with him on clothes, 1/5th of the remaining on food and 1/4th of the remaining on travel. Now, he is left with Rs 600. How much did he have with him in the beginning?
Options:
(A) s 200
(B) s 1500
(C) s 300
(D) s 450
(E) s 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 100 = 1500

The average amount with a group of seven numbers is Rs. 30. If the newly joined member has Rs. 60 with him, what was the average amount with the group before his joining the group?
Options:
(A) s. 25.6
(B) s. 25
(C) s. 16.6
(D) s. 26
(E) s. 25.6
column3:
Total members in the group = 7
Average amount = Rs. 30
Total amount with them = 7 * 30 = Rs. 210
One number has Rs. 60. So, the amount with remaining 6 people = 210 - 60 = Rs. 150
The average amount with them = 150/6 = Rs. 25

column1:

Options:

(B) 37
(C) 46
(D) 90
(E) 100
column3:
Sum of all the 13 results = 13 * 20 = 260
Sum of the first 7 of them = 8 * 20 = 160
Sum of the last 7 of them = 8 * 40 = 320
So, the 8th number = 260 + 160 - 320 = 100.

(B) Three
(C) One
(D) Two
(E) Four
column3:
Answer = C) One
Two digit numbers giving remainder 2 when divided by 9 = 11, 20, 29, 38, 47, 56, 65, 74, 83, 92
Two digit numbers giving remainder 5 when divided by 8 = 13, 21, 29, 37, 45, 53, 61, 69, 77, 85, 93
Common Numbers = 29 = 1

In a group of dogs and peacocks, the number of legs are 18 less than four times the number of heads How many peacocks are there in that group?
Options:
(A) 9
(B) 8
(C) 7
(D) 6
(E) 5
column3: Let the number of dogs be 'x' and the number of peacocks by 'y'. Then, number of legs in the group = 4x + 2y. Number of heads in the group = x+y So, 4x+2y = 4(x+y) – 18 ⇒ 2y = 18 ⇒ y = 9 Number of peacocks in that group = 9.

column1:
A person spends 1/3rd of the money with him on clothes, 1/5th of the remaining on food and 1/4th of the remaining on travel. Now, he is left with Rs 500. How much did he have with him in the beginning?
Options:
(A) s 200
(B) s 1250
(C) s 300
(D) s 450
(E) s 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 500 = 1250

column1:
The average age of a class of 32 students is 16 yrs. if the teacher's age is also included, the average increases by one year. Find the age of the teacher
Options:
(A) 30 Years
(B) 31 Years
(C) 32 Years
(D) 34 Years
(E) 49 Years
column3:
Total age of students is 32X16 = 512 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 33X (16+1) = 561
So, Teacher's age is 561-512 = 49 Yrs
There is a shortcut for these type of problems
Teacher's age is 16+(33X1) = 49 Years

column1:
At a meeting of the 9 Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Chief of Naval Operations does not want to sit next to the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. How many ways can the 9 Chiefs of Staff be seated around a circular table?

(A) 120
(B) 480
(C) 960
(D) 2520
(E) 6050
column3: Bunuel, I'm also a little confused with the number of arrangements of n distinct objects in a circle. Why is it given by (n-1)!. In theveritasanswer they say:answer E (6050), should be the number of ways to arrange all 7 without the seating restriction given. Is this incorrect?

column1:
X can finish a work in 18 days. Y can finish the same work in 15 days. Yworked for 10 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?
Options:
(A) 3
(B) 5
(C) 6
(D) 7
(E) 9
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/18
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/15
Work done by Y in 10 days = 10/15 = 2/3
Remaining work = 1 – 2/3 = 1/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (1/3) / (1/18) = 6

column1:
Two trains are traveling on parallel tracks in the same direction. The faster train travels at 130 miles per hour, while the slower train travels at 100 miles per hour. At 2 o’clock the faster train is 25 miles behind the slower one. How far apart are the two trains at 5 o'clock?
Options:
(A) 60 miles
(B) 80 miles
(C) 90 miles
(D) 65 miles
(E) 400 miles
column3:
Answer = D. 65 miles
Relational speed = 130 - 100 = 30 miles per hour
In 3 hours, difference = 30 * 3 = 90 miles
Fast train trailing 25 miles, so effective difference = 90 - 25 = 65 miles

From among the 39 students in a class, one leader and one class representative are to be appointed. In how many ways can this be done?

(B) 1260
(C) 1060
(D) 1482
(E) 1460
column3: There are 39 students and every one has equal chance of being selected as a leader. Hence, the leader can be appointed in 39 ways. When one person is appointed as leader, we are left with 35 students. Out of these 38 teachers, we can select one class representative. So, a class representative can be selected in 38 ways. Hence, the number of ways in which a leader and class representative can be selected = 39 x 38 = 1482

If n is an integer, then the least possible value of |8 - 9n| is?
Options:
(A) 0
(B) 1
(C) 2
(D) 3
(E) 11
column3: |8 - 9n| represents the distance between 8 and 9n on the number line. Now, the distance will be minimized when 9n, which is multiple of 9, is closest to 8. Multiple of 9 which is closest to 8 is 9 (for n = 1), so the least distance is 1: |8 - 9| = 1.

column1:
The flow of water through a drainage pipe was monitored for a 3-hour period. In the second hour, the rate of flow was 24 gallons per hour, which was 50 percent faster than the rate of flow for the first hour. If 25 percent more water flowed through the pipe in the third hour than it did in the second, how many gallons of water flowed through the pipe during the entire three hours?
Options:
(A) 61.25
(B) 62.5
(C) 63.75
(D) 70.0
(E) 77.5
column3:
Rate of flow of water in second hour = 24 gallons per hour
Rate of flow of water in first hour = 24/(3/2) = 16 gallons per hour
Rate of flow of water in third hour = (125/100)* 24 = (5/4) * 24 = 30 gallons per hour
Number of gallons of water that flowed through the pipe during the entire 3 hours = 16+24+30 = 70 gallons

A, B and C can do a piece of work in 20, 30 and 60 days respectively. In how many days can A do the work if he is assisted by B and C on every third day?
Options:
(A) 12 days
(B) 15 days
(C) 18 days
(D) 20 days
(E) 22 days
column3:
A’s two day’s work = 2/20 = 1/10
(A + B + C)’s one day’s work = 1/20 + 1/30 + 1/60 = 6/60 = 1/10
Work done in 3 days = (1/10 + 1/10) = 1/5
Now, 1/5 work is done in 3 days
Therefore, Whole work will be done in (3 x 5) = 15 days.

column3: Answer: A. There is exactly one. The prime factorization of 14 is 14 = 2*7, so N = 2*7*p = 7*2*p = 7*2p, so 2p is the only even number that divides N.

The number of people at Ovations Bar in the hour from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. was 20% greater than the number of people there from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. The number of the people at the bar from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. was 10% more than the number there from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. If 242 people were at the bar from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., which of the following is the number of people in the bar from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m.?
Options:
(A) 100
(B) 20
(C) 30
(D) 40
(E) 50
column3:
No of people from 10 - 11 is x
No of people from 11 - 12 is 11x/10
No of people from 12 to 1 is (6/5)(11x/10)
Given that 11x/10 + (6/5)(11x/10) = 121x / 50 = 242
Then x = 100

(E) 100

He has has ten patterns of chairs and eight patterns of tables

A table can be arranged in 7 ways
Hence one chair and one table can be arranged in 10 x 7 ways = 70 ways

column1:
The flow of water through a drainage pipe was monitored for a 3-hour period. In the second hour, the rate of flow was 36 gallons per hour, which was 50 percent faster than the rate of flow for the first hour. If 25 percent more water flowed through the pipe in the third hour than it did in the second, how many gallons of water flowed through the pipe during the entire three hours?
Options:
(A) 106.25
(B) 105.5
(C) 105.75
(D) 106
(E) 105.0
column3:
Rate of flow of water in second hour = 36 gallons per hour
Rate of flow of water in first hour = 36/(3/2) = 24 gallons per hour
Rate of flow of water in third hour = (125/100)* 36 = (5/4) * 36 = 45 gallons per hour
Number of gallons of water that flowed through the pipe during the entire 3 hours = 24+36+45 = 105 gallons

Steve gets on the elevator at the 11th floor of a building and rides up at a rate of 57 floors per minute. At the same time Joyce gets on an elevator on the 51st floor of the same building and rides down at a rate of 63 floors per minute. If they continue traveling at these rates, at which floor will their paths cross?
Options:
(A) 19
(B) 28
(C) 30
(D) 32
(E) 44
column3:
Using Speed Formula: Speed = Distance / Time
Distance to be covered = 51-11 = 40
Speed of approach = 57 + 63 floors/min
Time = 40/120 = 1/3
So Steve will cover 57x 1/3 floors in that time = 19
So he will be in 19 + 11 floor = 30th Floor

X can finish a work in 18 days. Y can finish the same work in 15 days. Yworked for 10 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?
Options:
(A) 2
(B) 3
(C) 6
(D) 8
(E) 9
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/18
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/15
Work done by Y in 10 days = 10/15 = 2/3
Remaining work = 1 – 2/3 = 1/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (1/3) / (1/18) = 6

column3: Total cost involved for each 75 $ shipment: 3+2 = 5 $. Thus, for two such orders = 10$\nTotal cost involved for a 150$ shipment: 3+3 = 6$. Thus, for two such orders = 12$\nThe difference = 2$.

The average of 13 numbers is 60. Average of the first 7 of them is 57 and that of the last 7 is 61. Find the 8th number?
Options:
(A) 46
(B) 82
(C) 45
(D) 43
(E) 53
column3:
Sum of all the 13 numbers = 13 * 60 = 780
Sum of the first 7 of them = 7 * 57 = 399
Sum of the last 7 of them = 7 * 61 = 427
So, the 8th number = 427 + 399 - 780 = 46.

Options:
(A) 46
(B) 48
(C) 50
(D) 52
(E) 54
column3:
Sum of all the 13 numbers = 13 * 60 = 780
Sum of the first 6 of them = 6 * 57 = 342
Sum of the last 8 of them = 8 * 61 = 488
So, the 8th number = 342 + 488 - 780 = 50.

Addition = 28+21+12 = 61

column1:
John has some chickens that have been laying him plenty of eggs. He wants to give away his eggs to several of his friends, but he wants to give them all the same number of eggs. He figures out that he needs to give 7 of his friends eggs for them to get the same amount, otherwise there is 1 extra egg left.
What is the least number of eggs he needs for this to be true?
Options:
(A) 201
(B) 301
(C) 401
(D) 101
(E) 501
column3: The number of eggs must be one more than a number that is divisible by 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 since each of these numbers leave a remainder of 1. For this to be true one less than the number must be divisible by 5, 4, and 3 (6 is 2*3 and 2 is a factor of 4 so they will automatically be a factor). 5 * 4 * 3 = 60. Then you just must find a multiple of 60 such that 60 * n + 1 is divisible by 7. 61 / 7, 121 / 7, 181 / 7, 241 / 7 all leave remainders but 301 / 7 doesn't.

(B) 4
(C) 8
(D) 10

column3: The sum of the first two (last two) digits cannot be 0 because 0000 is not a four-digit integer. If the sum of the first two digits is 1, two variants are possible: 1001 and 1010 (we have to remember that 0 cannot be the first digit). If the sum of the first two digits is 2, one variant is possible: 1111. In all, there are three numbers that satisfy the given conditions: 1001, 1010, and 1111.

Options:

(B) 42
(C) 1500
(D) 600
(E) 720
column3:
Vowel: E O
Consonants: V R M N T
First letter can be filled in 5 Ways ( As the question states that first letter has to be a consonant)
Fifth letter can be filled in 4 Ways ( As the question states that the last letter has to be a consonant)
Now since each letter can be used only once, and 2 letters out of 7 letters are already used in First and Fifth letter
Second letter can be filled in 5 Ways
Third letter can be filled in 4 Ways
Fourth letter can be filled in 3 Ways
So, Total number of ways = 5 Ways x 5 Ways x 4 ways x 3 ways x 5 ways = 1500

(A) 15
(B) 18
(C) 16
(D) 12
(E) 19
column3:
Present age of total members = 6 X 26 = 156
10 yrs back their ages were = 6 x 10 = 60
Ages at the birth of youngest member = 156 - 60 = 96
Therefore, avg age at the birth of youngest member = 96/6 = 16.

column3: The square roots of all numbers from answer choices are between 9 and 10, so the product of primes of the number we are looking should be less then 9, so this number should have only 2-s, only 3-s, only 5-s, or only 2-s and 3-s as its primes. Only 96 satisfies this.

column3:

So, the 8th number = 427 + 392 - 780 = 39.

column1:
If 20m − n = p, then which of the following represents the average (arithmetic mean) of m, n, and p, in terms of m?
Options:
(A) 2m −1
(B) 4m
(C) 6m
(D) 7m
(E) 6m/5
column3:
20m - n = p
Add n to both sides:
20m = n + p
Add m to both sides:
21m = n + p + m
Now, divide both sides by 3
7m = (n + p + m)/3 = the average of n, p, and m

column3:

Total time taken = x + 2x = 3x
Average speed = 108x/3x = 36

column3: 7g/30 tells us that g is a factor of 30, which has 2, 3, and 5 as its prime factors. Each of them is distinct. Moreover, all multiples of 30 less than 200 can be derived by multiplying these prime factors alone. Thus, number of different prime factors is 3.

column3:

Relational speed = 130 - 100 = 30 miles per hour

Fast train trailing 15 miles, so effective difference = 60 - 15 = 45 miles

Options:

(D) 51 Years

column3:
Total age of students is 32X16 = 512 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 33X (16+1) = 561

There is a shortcut for these type of problems

There are 10 students named alphabetically from A to J. What is the Probability that A and D do not sit together if all 10 sit around a circular table?
Options:
(A) 2/9
(B) 2/5
(C) 7/9
(D) 4/5
(E) 8/9
column3:
Number of students = 10
Number of ways 10 students can sit around a circular table = (10 - 1)! = 9!
Number of ways A and D sit together (consider A and D as one entity) = (9 - 1)! = 8! * 2
Number of ways A and D do not sit together = 9! - (8! * 2)
Probability = (9! - (8! * 2))/9! = 1 - 2/9 = 7/9

A car traveled from San Diego to San Francisco at an average speed of 63 miles per hour. If the journey back took twice as long, what was the average speed of the trip?
Options:
(A) 24.
(B) 32.
(C) 36.
(D) 42.
(E) 44.
column3:
Let the time taken be = x
One way distance = 63x
Total distance traveled = 2 * 63x = 126x
Total time taken = x + 2x = 3x
Average speed = 126x/3x = 42

Options:

column3: There were 36*5 = 180 total votes made. If each voter picked 3 coaches, there were 180/3 = 60 voters.

Every day, Fred takes the train to travel from his work back to Alkmaar, his place of residence. Usually, he arrives at the station of Alkmaar at six o'clock, and exactly at that moment, his wife picks him up by car. Yesterday evening, Fred took an earlier train, without informing his wife, and therefore he already was at the station of Alkmaar at five o'clock. He decided to walk part of the way to meet his wife. When he met the car with his wife, he drove home with her. In this way, they were home ten minutes earlier than normal. Fred's wife always drives the entire way between home and station at the same constant speed.How long did Fred walk yesterday evening?
Options:
(A) 55
(B) 45
(C) 58
(D) 65
(E) 59
column3: Fred's wife needed to drive ten minutes less than usual, which is five minutes less in the direction of the station and five minutes less back home. Therefore, Fred met his wife at five minutes to six. He had walked already since five o'clock, so he walked 55 minutes in total.

column1:
At the A-Street Fish Market a vendor sells fresh caught fish. His store is filled with 2/7 bass, 1/5 tuna, 1/7 trout, and the rest are catfish. If a customer just bought 1/7 of all the tuna and 1/7 of all the catfish, and a fisherman arrived to restock the bass, doubling the number of bass, what proportion of fish now in the store are trout?
Options:
(A) 30/71
(B) 4/7
(C) 5/43
(D) 1/2
(E) 1/5
column3:
Bass = 2/7 = 10/35
Tuna = 1/5 = 7/35
Trout = 1/7 = 5/35
Catfish = 1 - (10/35 +7/35 + 5/35) = 13/35
Purchased: Tuna = 7/35 - (7/35)(1/7) = 6/35, and
Catfish = 13/35 - (13/35)(1/7) = 12/35
Stocked: doubling the number of bass (2)(10/35) = 20/35
Now: 20 + 6 + 5 + 12 = 43
Trout proportion is now 5/43.

X can finish a work in 18 days. Y can finish the same work in 15 days. Yworked for 10 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?
Options:
(A) 2
(B) 3
(C) 6
(D) 7
(E) 8
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/18
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/15
Work done by Y in 10 days = 10/15 = 2/3
Remaining work = 1 – 2/3 = 1/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (1/3) / (1/18) = 6

column1:
If x>0, y>0, and |x| > |y|, which of the following must be true?
Options:
(A) x > y
(B) y^2 > x^2
(C) x^3 > y^2
(D) –x < y
(E) x < –y
column3: Correct Answer: (E)\nLet’s go through each answer choice: (A) can never be true, since no negative is greater than a positive. (B) doesn’t have to be true – consider what would happen if x = -2 and y = 1. (C) can never be true, as x^3 must be negative, and y^2 must be positive. (D) can never be true, since if x < 0, -x is the same thing as |x|, and |x| > y. (E) can be manipulated by multiplying both sides by -1, which gives us –x > y. Remember that x < 0, so –x = |x|, and y is positive, so |y| = y. Thus x > y is the same statement as |x| > |y|, and (A) must be true.

How many digits are in the number 50^8 × 8^3 × 11^2 x 10^2?
Options:
(A) 22
(B) 20
(C) 21
(D) 18
(E) 17
column3:
Whenever you are asked to find the number of digits, try to bring the number in multiples of 10. This way, we can wasily calculate the umber of 0's through the powers of 10
50^8 × 8^3 × 11^2 x 10^2 = (5^2*2)^8*2^9*11^2x 10^2 = 5^16*2^17*11^2 x10^2 = 2*11^2*10^16x10^2 = 242*10^18
Hence we would have 16 trailing 0's and the three digits from 242
Total digits = 3 + 18 = 21

If n is the smallest integer such that 432 times n is the square of an integer, what is the value of n?
Options:
(A) 2
(B) 3
(C) 6
(D) 12
(E) 24
column3: The prime factorization of a square has to have even powers of all its prime factors. If the original number has a factor, say of 7, then when it’s squared, the square will have a factor of 7^2. Another way to say that is: any positive integer all of whose prime factors have even powers must be a perfect square of some other integer. Look at the prime factorization of 432\n432 = (2^4)*(3^3)\nThe factor of 2 already has an even power —- that’s all set. The factor of 3 currently has an odd power. If n = 3, then 432*n would have an even power of 2 and an even power of 3; therefore, it would be a perfect square. Thus, n = 3 is a choice that makes 432*n a perfect square.

Option A: 10394, Sum = 17. Not divisible by 3. Hence the number 10394 is also not divisible by 3
Option B: 15363, Sum = 18, Divisible by 3

column3:
Time taken for train A = 30 minutes + d1/s1 = 30 minutes + 100 / 100 = 1 hours 30 minutes

Time taken for train B = d2/s2 = 100 / 50 = 2 Hours
So Train A reaches 30 minutes before Train B

column3: Start with the prime factorization:\n33150 = 50*663 = (2*5*5)*3*221 = (2)*(3)*(5^2)*(13)*(17)\nThere are five distinct prime factors, {2, 3, 5, 13, and 17}

(B) 80 miles
(C) 90 miles
(D) 120 miles

column3:
Answer = A. 20 miles
Relational speed = 110 - 100 = 10 miles per hour
In 6 hours, difference = 10 * 6 = 60 miles
Fast train trailing 40 miles, so effective difference = 60 - 40 = 20 miles

Ratio of average speed of Eddy to Freddy = 160/75 = 32/15

column3: The prompt is essentially asking for the maximum number of 2 x 2 squares that can be cut from a larger 20 by 20 square. Since each 'row' and each 'column' of the larger square can be sub-divided into 10 'pieces' each, we have (10)(10) = 100 total smaller squares (at maximum).

column3: P = P(A wins, B wins, C loses) + P(A wins, B loses, C wins) + P(A loses, B wins, C wins) = 1/5*3/8*4/7 + 1/5*5/8*3/7 + 4/5*3/8*3/7 = 63/280.

(C) s. 16.6

column3:
Total members in the group = 7

column1:
If 14m − n = p, then which of the following represents the average (arithmetic mean) of m, n, and p, in terms of m?
Options:
(A) 2m −1
(B) 4m
(C) 5m
(D) m/5
(E) 6m/5
column3:
14m - n = p
Add n to both sides:
14m = n + p
Add m to both sides:
15m = n + p + m
Now, divide both sides by 3
5m = (n + p + m)/3 = the average of n, p, and m

A Martian bat flies at 60 yards per second from its nest to a dry lake. When it arrives there, it immediately continues at 45 yards per second to a nearby cave. If the distance between the lake and the cave is half the distance between the nest and the lake, what is the average speed, in yards per second, of the bat during the whole flight?
Options:
(A) 36

(C) 42
(D) 54
(E) 65
column3: Distance from nest to lake = d, Speed = 60, Time = d/60\nDistance from lake to cave = d/2, Speed = 45, Time = d/90\nAverage speed = (d + d/2)/(d/60 + d/90) = (3/2)/(1/36) = 54

column3: Largest 5 digit number is 99999\nAfter doing 99999 ÷ 88 we get remainder 31\nHence largest 5 digit number exactly divisible by 88 = 99999 - 31 = 99968

column1:
If x<0, y>0, and |x| < |y|, which of the following must be true?
Options:
(A) x > y
(B) y^2 > x^2
(C) x^3 > y^2
(D) –x < y
(E) x < –y
column3: Correct Answer: (E)\nLet’s go through each answer choice: (A) can never be true, since no negative is greater than a positive. (B) doesn’t have to be true – consider what would happen if x = -2 and y = 1. (C) can never be true, as x^3 must be negative, and y^2 must be positive. (D) can never be true, since if x < 0, -x is the same thing as |x|, and |x| > y. (E) can be manipulated by multiplying both sides by -1, which gives us –x > y. Remember that x < 0, so –x = |x|, and y is positive, so |y| = y. Thus –x < y is the same statement as |x| > |y|, and (D) must be true.

Options:

(B) 1260
(C) 1060
(D) 1160
(E) 930
column3: There are 31 students and every one has equal chance of being selected as a leader. Hence, the leader can be appointed in 31 ways. When one person is appointed as leader, we are left with 35 students. Out of these 30 teachers, we can select one class representative. So, a class representative can be selected in 30 ways. column1:
In the x-y plane, point (x, y) is a lattice point if both x and y are integers. Circle C has a center at (-2, -2) and a diameter of 8. Some points, such as the center (-2, -2), are inside the circle, but a point such as (-2, 2) is on the circle but not in the circle. How many lattice points are in circle C?
Options:
(A) 40
(B) 10
(C) 73
(D) 60
(E) 63
column3: The lattice points that are in the circle that lie on the perspective axes is as follows: since the diameter is 8, 9 points lie on the horizontal axis (8 + center), but the end points are not in the circle, so 9 - 2 (the same for the vertical axis, but don't count center again), 7 - 1. The lattice points in the circle and not on the horizontal and vertical axes is as follows: lattice points can be found at 45, 45/2 and 30 degrees of axes (30 and 45/2 degrees from horizontal and vertical axes), so same numbers as before, but don't count center again. So, 13 + 5 * 12 = 73\nThere are a total of 73 lattice points in the circle.

(B) 4/9
(C) 5/9
(D) 2/3
(E) 3/4
column3: In Hockey game, Probably the easiest approach would be to find the probability of the opposite event and subtract it from 1:\nP(win) = 1- P(not win) = 1 - 4/6*4/6 = 5/9.

column3:
Total distance = 8 Km

Required speed = 5/1/3 = 15 Kmph

column1:
Alice, Benjamin, and Carol each try independently to win a carnival game. If their individual probabilities for success are 1/5, 3/8, and 2/7, respectively, what is the probability that exactly two of the three players will win but one will lose?
Options:
(A) 3/140
(B) 1/28
(C) 3/56
(D) 3/35
(E) 7/40
column3: P = P(A wins, B wins, C loses) + P(A wins, B loses, C wins) + P(A loses, B wins, C wins) = 1/5*3/8*5/7 + 1/5*5/8*2/7 + 4/5*3/8*2/7 = 7/40.

column1:
Eddy and Freddy start simultaneously from city A and they travel to City B and City C respectively. Eddy takes 3 hours and Freddy takes 4 hours to complete the journey. If the distance between City A and City B is 540 kms and City A and City C is 300 kms. What is the ratio of their average speed of travel? (Eddy: Freddy)
Options:
(A) 8/3
(B) 3/8
(C) 8/5
(D) 12/5
(E) 5/3
column3:
Distance traveled by Eddy = 540 km
Time taken by Eddy = 3 hours
Average speed of Eddy = 540/3 = 180 km/hour
Distance traveled by Freddy = 300 km
Time taken by Freddy = 4 hours
Average speed of Freddy = 300/4 = 75 km/hour
Ratio of average speed of Eddy to Freddy = 180/75 = 12/5

(D) 14
(E) 18
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/21

Remaining work = 1 – 1/3 = 2/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (2/3) / (1/21) = 14

(C) 90

column3: According to the information in the question the maximum range would be between 610 and 780(170). The minimum range would be the greatest range for any one individual, which is listed in the problem as 90. So the difference between these would be 170-90 or 80.

column3: Average weight = [(a + b + c + (a+b) + (b+c) + (c+a)+(a+b+c)] / 7 = 4 (a+b+c) /7 = 4 x 175/7 = 100 kgs

column1:
How many numbers can be made with digits 0, 7, 8 which are greater than 0 and less than a million?
Options:
(A) 496
(B) 486
(C) 1084
(D) 728
(E) 628
column3:
The number of single digit numbers = 2
The number of 2 digit numbers = 2 × 3 = 6
The number of 3 digit numbers = 2 × 3 × 3 = 18
The number of 4 digit numbers = 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 54
The number of 5 digit numbers = 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 162
The number of 6 digit numbers = 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 3 = 486
Therefore, the total numbers = 728

Ronald and Elan are working on an assignment. Ronald takes 6 hrs to type 32 pages on a computer, while Elan takes 5 hrs to type 40 pages. How much time will they take, working together on two different computers to type an assignment of 110 pages?
Options:
(A) 8 hrs 85 min
(B) 8 hrs 18 min
(C) 8 hrs 15 min
(D) 6 hrs 15 min
(E) 3 hrs 15 min
column3:
Number of pages typed by Ronald in 1 hour = 32/6 = 16/3
Number of pages typed by Elan in 1 hour = 40/5 = 8
Number of pages typed by both in 1 hour = (16/3 + 8) = 40/3
Time taken by both to type 110 pages = (110 * 3/40) = 8 1/4 = 8 hrs 15 min

The average marks of a Suresh in 10 papers are 80. If the highest and the lowest scores are not considered, the average is 81. If his highest score is 92, find the lowest?
Options:
(A) 55
(B) 60
(C) 62
(D) 52
(E) Cannot be determined
column3:
Total marks of 10 papers = 80 x 10 = 800
Total marks of 8 papers = 81 x 8 = 648
Total marks of two papers = (800 - 648) = 152
If highest total is 92, then the lowest total is
(152 - 92) = 60.

column1:
From a Group of 9 People, Including George and Nina, 4 people are to be selected at random to work on a certain project. What is the probability that 4 people selected will include George but not Nina
Options:
(A) 5/56
(B) 9/56
(C) 15/56
(D) 35/120
(E) 25/56
column3:
Number of ways of selecting 4 people out of 9 people = 9C4
In the three members George will always be there in the team. At this step we have vacancy for 3 more members and 8 members are available. Nina cannot be there in the team. So 3 members have to be selected and the number of available members = 8 - Nina = 7
Number of ways to form a 4 member team that includes George and excludes Nina = 7C3
Probability = 7C3/9C4 = 35/120

column3: Left After 1st stroke = 1/2\nLeft After 2nd stroke = 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4\nSo removed = 1- 1/4 = 3/4

column1:
Sum Sam and Product Pete are in class when their teacher gives Sam the Sum of two numbers and Pete the product of the same two numbers (these numbers are greater than or equal to 2). They must figure out the two numbers.
Sam: I don't know what the numbers are Pete.
Pete: I knew you didn't know the numbers... But neither do I.
Sam: In that case, I do know the numbers.1
What are the numbers?
Options:
(A) 1-2
(B) 1-3
(C) 2-4
(D) 3-4
(E) 2-3
column3: Since Sam knows the sum of the numbers (x + y) he would only know the answer immediately if the sum was 4 (2 + 2) or 5 (3 + 2). Then when Pete (who knows x*y) knew that Sam didn't know the answer the product must have several numbers that add up to the sum (7 = 3 + 4, 7 = 5 + 2). When Pete doesn't know the answer at this point we know the product must have more than one pair of viable factors (12 = 3 * 4, 12 = 6 * 2). At this point Sam knows the numbers are 3 and 4 because they are the only numbers that meet these criteria.

During a particular baseball game, the probability of a team's pitcher throwing a strike on each throw is 2/5. What is the least number of times that the pitcher should pitch the ball that will increase the probability of getting a strike at least once to more than 50%.
Options:

(B) 2
(C) 1
(D) 4
(E) 5
column3: Rule of Subtraction: P(A) = 1 - P(A')\nRule of Multiplication: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) P(B)\nThe probability that the pitcher throws a strike at least once in 2 guesses is 1- (3/5)^2 = 1 - 9/25 = 16/25 > 50%.

Jack has two dice, one has six equally probable sides, labeled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and the other has seven equally probable sides, labeled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. If Jack rolls both dice what is the probability that both of the number's sum will be 13?

(B) 2/7
(C) 1/3

column3:
Both Dice addition result is 13 = (6+7)
Probability that the number on first die is 6 = 1/6

An archer is shooting arrows from various distances. She shoots at a target from 30 yards, 40 yards, and 50 yards. The probability that she hits within the bullseye from 30 yards is 5/6, the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 40 yards is 4/5, and the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 50 yards is 3/4. What is the probability that she hits the bullseye at least once in three shots, one from each distance listed.
Options:
(A) 104/105
(B) 119/120
(C) 139/140
(D) 9/10
(E) 14/15
column3:
The probability that she hits the bullseye at least once = 1 - (the probability that she misses the bullseye every shot)
The probability that she misses all shots = (prob that she misses from 30 yards)*(prob that she misses from 40 yards)*(prob that she misses from 50 yards)
Prob that she misses from 30 yards = 1 - 5/6 = 1/6; Prob that she misses from 40 yards = 1 - 4/5 = 1/5; Prob that she misses from 50 yards = 1 - 3/4 = 1/4
Thus the probability that she misses all shots = (1/6)*(1/5)*(1/4) = 1/120
Thus the probability that she makes at least one shot = 1 - (1/120) = 119/120

column1:
If x<0, y<0, and |x| > |y|, which of the following must be true?
Options:
(A) x > y
(B) y^2 > x^2
(C) x^3 > y^2
(D) x < y
(E) x < –y
column3: Correct Answer: (E)\nLet’s go through each answer choice: (A) can never be true, since no negative is greater than a positive. (B) doesn’t have to be true – consider what would happen if x = -2 and y = 1. (C) can never be true, as x^3 must be negative, and y^2 must be positive. (D) can never be true, since if x < 0, -x is the same thing as |x|, and |x| > y. (E) can be manipulated by multiplying both sides by -1, which gives us –x > y. Remember that x < 0, so –x = |x|, and y is positive, so |y| = y. Thus x < y is the same statement as |x| > |y|, and (D) must be true.

Options:
(A) x+y
(B) x+2y
(C) 3x+y
(D) x+y^2
(E) x+y+2
column3:
Plug in an even integer for x; in this case 2
Plug in an odd integer for y; in this case 1
2+1 = 3 Odd
2+(2*1) = 4 Even
(3*2)+1 = 6 + 1 = 7 Odd
2+(1^2) = 2 + 1 = 3 Odd
2+1+2 = 5 Odd

A person spends 1/3rd of the money with him on clothes, 1/5th of the remaining on food and 1/4th of the remaining on travel. Now, he is left with Rs 100. How much did he have with him in the beginning?
Options:
(A) Rs 200
(B) Rs 250
(C) Rs 300
(D) Rs 450
(E) Rs 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 100 = 250

The number of people at Ovations Bar in the hour from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. was 20% greater than the number of people there from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. The number of the people at the bar from 11 a.m. to 12 p.m. was 10% more than the number there from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. If 121 people were at the bar from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., which of the following is the number of people in the bar from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m.?
Options:
(A) 10
(B) 20
(C) 30
(D) 40
(E) 50
column3:
No of people from 10 - 11 is x
No of people from 11 - 12 is 11x/10
No of people from 12 to 1 is (6/5)(11x/10)
Given that 11x/10 + (6/5)(11x/10) = 121x / 50 = 121
Then x = 50

A and B can do a work in 12 days, B and C in 30 days and C and A in 36 days. In how many days will the work be completed, if all three of them work together?

(B) 160/13 days
(C) 180/13 days
(D) 680/13 days
(E) 180/63 days
column3:
One day work of A and B = 1/12
One day work of B and C = 1/30
One day work of C and A = 1/36
2(A + B + C) = 1/12 + 1/30 + 1/36
2(A + B + C) = 13/90
(A + B + C) = 13/180
Number of days required = 180/13 days.

Distance covered is equal to the length of the train = 200 m

If 23m − n = p, then which of the following represents the average (arithmetic mean) of m, n, and p, in terms of m?
Options:
(A) 2m −1
(B) 4m
(C) 6m
(D) m/5
(E) 8m
column3:
23m - n = p
Add n to both sides:
23m = n + p
Add m to both sides:
24m = n + p + m
Now, divide both sides by 3
8m = (n + p + m)/3 = the average of n, p, and m

column3:
A's one day's work = 1/15

Ronald and Elan are working on an assignment. Ronald takes 6 hours to type 32 pages on a computer, while Elan takes 5 hours to type 40 pages. How much time will they take, working together on two different computers to type an assignment of 110 pages?
Options:
(A) 3 hours
(B) 6 hours
(C) 4 hours
(D) 8 hours
(E) 10 hours
column3:
Number of pages typed by Ronald in one hour = 32/6 = 16/3
Number of pages typed by Elan in one hour = 40/5 = 8
Number of pages typed by both in one hour = ((16/3) + 8) = 40/3
Therefore, time taken by both to type 110 pages = 110 x 3/40 = 8 hours.

column3:

Consonants: V R M N T
First letter can be filled in 2 Ways ( As the question states that first letter has to be a vowel)
Fifth letter can be filled in 1 Ways ( As the question states that the last letter has to be a vowel)

So, Total number of ways = 2 Ways x 5 Ways x 4 ways x 1 ways = 40

Here, distance to be covered is constant
∴ S × 8 = (S + 5)(20⁄3)
⇒ 8S - 20⁄3S = 100⁄3 ⇒ S = 100⁄4 = 25 km/h

column3: The total possibilities are W@W@W@ (or) @W@W@W, where 2 blue and 1 red flowers occupy the space marked as @. Hence, the Total number of permutations is 2 x (3! / 2!) = 6.

column1:
If n is an integer, then the least possible value of |15 - 8n| is?
Options:
(A) 0
(B) 2
(C) 1
(D) 3
(E) 5
column3: |15 - 8n| represents the distance between 15 and 8n on the number line. Now, the distance will be minimized when 8n, which is multiple of 8, is closest to 15. Multiple of 8 which is closest to 15 is 16 (for n = 2), so the least distance is 1: |15 - 16| = 1.

Jasmine has a toaster with two slots that toasts one side of each piece of bread at a time, and it takes one minute to do so.
If she wants to make 3 pieces of toast, what is the least amount of time she needs to toast them on both sides?
Options:
(A) 1
(B) 2
(C) 3 min
(D) 4
(E) 5
column3: 3 minutes. She puts two pieces in the toaster, toasting one side of each. Then she flips one of them, takes one out, and puts the completely untoasted piece into the toaster. Finally, she takes out the toasted piece and puts the two half-toasted pieces of bread into the toaster for a minute and she's done.

A and B can do a work in 12 days, B and C in 30 days and C and A in 36 days. In how many days will the work be completed, if all three of them work together?
Options:

(B) 180/15
(C) 180/13
(D) 180/12
(E) 180/11
column3:
One day work of A and B = 1/12
One day work of B and C = 1/30
One day work of C and A = 1/36
2(A + B + C) = 1/12 + 1/30 + 1/36
2(A + B + C) = 13/90
(A + B + C) = 13/180
Number of days required = 180/13 days.

189. The inside dimensions of a rectangular wooden box
are 10 inches by 12 inches by 14 inches. A cylindrical
canister is to be placed inside the box so that it stands
upright when the closed box rests on one of its six
faces. Of all such canisters that could be used, what is
the radius, in inches, of the one that has maximum
volume?
Options:
(A)  3
(B)  4
(C)  5
(D)  6
(E)  8
column3: Since the radius is squared, the biggest volume cylinder will have the biggest possible radius. To achieve that, let the smaller dimension of the rectangular box be the height. So, it will have 14x12 width x length. The biggest cylinder must fit both dimensions, so it must have at most a diameter of 12, so the radius will be 6.

A family pays $800 per year for an insurance plan that pays 85 percent of the first $1,000 in expenses and 100 percent of all medical expenses thereafter. In any given year, the total amount paid by the family will equal the amount paid by the plan when the family's medical expenses total.
Options:
(A) $1,100
(B) $1,200
(C) $1,400
(D) $1,800
(E) $2,200
column3:
Upfront payment for insurance plan = 800$
Family needs to pay 15 % of first 1000 $ in expense = 150$
Total amount paid by family when medical expenses are equal to or greater than 1000 $ = 800 + 150 = 950 $
Total amount paid by insurance plan for first 1000 $ = 800 $
Total amount paid by family will equal amount paid by plan when medical expense = 1100 $
(Since insurance plan will pay 100% of amount that exceeds 950$ )

column3:
Convert 30 seconds to 1/2 minute
Equation: 1/r = 1/(r + 1) + 1/2
Plug options into the equation:
D fits: 1/1 = 1/(1 + 1) + 1/2

(B) 22 & 146
(C) 23 & 145
(D) 20 & 140
(E) None
column3: Compound Interest: Total Balance = P(1 + R)T P = principle = starting balance = $124 R = interest rate = 4% T = time = 4 years Total balance = principle × (1 + interest rate)time = 124 × (1 + (4 / 100))4 = 145 Interest accrued = total balance - starting balance = 145 - 124 = 21

column1:
An archer is shooting arrows from various distances. She shoots at a target from 40 yards, 50 yards, and 60 yards. The probability that she hits within the bullseye from 40 yards is 4/5, the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 50 yards is 3/4, and the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 60 yards is 2/3. What is the probability that she hits the bullseye at least once in three shots, one from each distance listed.
Options:
(A) 39/40
(B) 49/50
(C) 59/60
(D) 9/10
(E) 14/15
column3:
The probability that she hits the bullseye at least once = 1 - (the probability that she misses the bullseye every shot)
The probability that she misses every shot = (prob that she misses from 40 yards)*(prob that she misses from 50 yards)*(prob that she misses from 60 yards)
Prob that she misses from 40 yards = 1 - 4/5 = 1/5; Prob that she misses from 50 yards = 1 - 3/4 = 1/4; Prob that she misses from 60 yards = 1 - 2/3 = 1/3
Thus the probability that she misses all shots = (1/5)*(1/4)*(1/3) = 1/60
Thus the probability that she makes at least one shot = 1 - (1/60) = 59/60

Options:

(B) s 500
(C) s 300
(D) s 450
(E) s 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 200 = 500

column3: |33 - 5n| represents the distance between 33 and 5n on the number line. Now, the distance will be minimized when 5n, which is multiple of 5, is closest to 33. Multiple of 5 which is closest to 33 is 35 (for n = 7), so the least distance is 2: |33 - 35| = 2.

column3:
1 man's 1 day work = 1/100

1 woman's 1 day work = 1/225
1 woman alone can complete the work in 225 days.

column3:
# components A and B could manufacture efficiently:
A: 50*70% = 35

Total = n(A) + n(B) - Both + None
None = Total - n(A) - n(B) + Both
Calculate "none" for each case
None(5+ yrs Line) = 200 - 50 - 40 + 30 = 140
None(5+ yrs Staff) = 160 - 40 - 50 + 20 = 90
Employees not taking either workshop/Total number of employees = (140 + 90)/(200 + 160) = 230/360 = About 64%

column1:
An archer is shooting arrows from various distances. She shoots at a target from 60 yards, 70 yards, and 80 yards. The probability that she hits within the bullseye from 60 yards is 2/3, the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 70 yards is 3/5, and the probability that she hits within the bullseye from 80 yards is 1/2. What is the probability that she hits the bullseye at least once in three shots, one from each distance listed.
Options:
(A) 19/20
(B) 29/30
(C) 49/50
(D) 9/10
(E) 14/15
column3:
The probability that she hits the bullseye at least once = 1 - (the probability that she misses the bullseye every shot)
The probability that she misses every shot = (prob that she misses from 60 yards)*(prob that she misses from 70 yards)*(prob that she misses from 80 yards)
Prob that she misses from 60 yards = 1 - 2/3 = 1/3; Prob that she misses from 70 yards = 1 - 3/5 = 2/5; Prob that she misses from 80 yards = 1 - 1/2 = 1/2
Thus the probability that she misses all shots = (1/3)*(2/5)*(1/2) = 2/30 = 1/15
Thus the probability that she makes at least one shot = 1 - (1/15) = 14/15

From among the 36 students in a class, one leader and one class representative are to be appointed. In how many ways can this be done?
Options:
(A) 1360
(B) 1260
(C) 1060
(D) 1160
(E) 1460
column3: There are 36 students and every one has equal chance of being selected as a leader. Hence, the leader can be appointed in 36 ways. When one person is appointed as leader, we are left with 35 students. Out of these 35 teachers, we can select one class representative. So, a class representative can be selected in 35 ways. Hence, the number of ways in which a leader and class representative can be selected = 36 x 35 = 1260

Present age of total members = 6 X 40 = 240

Ages at the birth of youngest member = 240 - 42 = 198

3150*y = A^2

column1:
The average amount with a group of seven numbers is Rs. 20. If the newly joined member has Rs. 50 with him, what was the average amount with the group before his joining the group?
Options:
(A) 28
(B) 27
(C) 15
(D) 19
(E) 12
column3:
Total members in the group = 7
Average amount = Rs. 20
Total amount with them = 7 * 20 = Rs. 140
One number has Rs. 50. So, the amount with remaining 6 people = 140 - 50 = Rs. 90
The average amount with them = 90/6 = Rs. 15.

column1:
X can finish a work in 21 days. Y can finish the same work in 15 days. Yworked for 10 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?
Options:
(A) 3
(B) 5
(C) 7
(D) 8
(E) 9
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/21
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/15
Work done by Y in 10 days = 10/15 = 2/3
Remaining work = 1 – 2/3 = 1/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (1/3) / (1/21) = 7

The average age of a class of 40 students is 15 yrs. if the teacher's age is also included, the average increases by one year. Find the age of the teacher
Options:
(A) 30 Years
(B) 56 Years
(C) 32 Years
(D) 34 Years
(E) 49 Years
column3:
Total age of students is 40X15 = 600 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 41X (15+1) = 656
So, Teacher's age is 656-600 = 56 Yrs
There is a shortcut for these type of problems
Teacher's age is 15+(41X1) = 56 Years

column1:
A and B can do a work in 2 days, B and C in 6 days and C and A in 8 days. In how many days will the work be completed, if all three of them work together?
Options:
(A) 12/28
(B) 48/19
(C) 16/48
(D) 18/48
(E) 12/64
column3:
One day work of A and B = 1/2
One day work of B and C = 1/6
One day work of C and A = 1/8
2(A + B + C) = 1/2 + 1/6 + 1/8
2(A + B + C) = 19/24
(A + B + C) = 19/48
Number of days required = 48/19 days.

column3: 3 minutes. She puts two pieces in the toaster, toasting one side of each. Then she flips one of them, takes one out, and puts the completely untoasted piece into the toaster. column1:
A family pays $800 per year for an insurance plan that pays 70 percent of the first $1,000 in expenses and 100 percent of all medical expenses thereafter. In any given year, the total amount paid by the family will equal the amount paid by the plan when the family's medical expenses total.
Options:
(A) $1,000
(B) $1,200
(C) $1,400
(D) $1,800
(E) $2,200
column3:
Upfront payment for insurance plan = 800$
Family needs to pay 30 % of first 1000 $ in expense = 300$
Total amount paid by family when medical expenses are equal to or greater than 1000 $ = 800 + 300 = 1100 $
Total amount paid by insurance plan for first 1000 $ = 800 $
Total amount paid by family will equal amount paid by plan when medical expense = 1400 $
(Since insurance plan will pay 100% of amount that exceeds 1100$ )

column3: 7b/30 tells us that b is a factor of 30, which has 2, 3, and 5 as its prime factors. Each of them is distinct. Moreover, all multiples of 30 less than 200 can be derived by multiplying these prime factors alone. Thus, number of different prime factors is 3.

Joel sailed for 3 hours at a speed of 20 miles per hour, then for 6 hours at 30 miles per hour and finally, 1 more hour at 40 miles per hour. What was the average speed of Joel during the whole sail?
.
Options:
(A) 25
(B) 27.5
(C) 28
(D) 30
(E) 32
column3:
3 hours at a speed of 20 miles per hour gives us Distance = 20*3 = 60 miles
6 hours at a speed of 30 miles per hour gives us Distance = 30*6 = 180 miles
1 more hour at 40 miles per hour gives us Distance = 40*1 = 40 miles
Total Distance = 60+180+40 = 280 miles
Total Time = 3+6+1 = 10 Hours
Average Speed = 280 / 10 = 28 Miles per hour

column1:
If x<0, y>0, and |x| < |y|, which of the following must be true?
Options:
(A) x > y
(B) y^2 > x^2
(C) x^3 > y^2
(D) –x > y
(E) x < –y
column3: Correct Answer: (E)\nLet’s go through each answer choice: (A) can never be true, since no negative is greater than a positive. (B) doesn’t have to be true – consider what would happen if x = -2 and y = 1. (C) can never be true, as x^3 must be negative, and y^2 must be positive. (D) can never be true, since if x < 0, -x is the same thing as |x|, and |x| > y. (E) can be manipulated by multiplying both sides by -1, which gives us –x > y. Remember that x < 0, so –x = |x|, and y is positive, so |y| = y. Thus –x > y is the same statement as |x| > |y|, and (D) must be true.

column3:

So removed = 1- 1/32 = 31/32

column3: Total # of codes possible is 3*3*3 = 27. Oit of those 27 codes only the product of 555 will be odd, the remaining 26 will have either 2 or 4 in them, which ensures that their product will be even. Therefore the number of codes where the product of the digits is even = (total) - (restriction) = 27 - 26 = 1.

Options:
(A) 140
(B) 146
(C) 152
(D) 162
(E) 170
column3:
Number of newborns that can die in first month = 1/10 * 200 = 20
Survived = 180
Number of newborns that can die in second month = 1/10 * 180 = 18
Survived = 162
Number of newborns that can die in third month = 1/10 * 162 = 16
Survived = 146

column3:
Sum of all the 13 numbers = 13 * 60 = 780

So, the 8th number = 427 + 399 - 780 = 46.

Eddy and Freddy start simultaneously from city A and they travel to City B and City C respectively. Eddy takes 3 hours and Freddy takes 4 hours to complete the journey. If the distance between City A and City B is 570 kms and City A and City C is 300 kms. What is the ratio of their average speed of travel? (Eddy: Freddy)
Options:
(A) 8/3
(B) 3/8
(C) 38/15
(D) 5/8
(E) 5/3
column3:
Distance traveled by Eddy = 570 km
Time taken by Eddy = 3 hours
Average speed of Eddy = 570/3 = 190 km/hour
Distance traveled by Freddy = 300 km
Time taken by Freddy = 4 hours
Average speed of Freddy = 300/4 = 75 km/hour
Ratio of average speed of Eddy to Freddy = 190/75 = 38/15

column1:
You have a flashlight that takes 2 working batteries. You have 8 batteries but only 4 of them work.
What is the fewest number of pairs you need to test to guarantee you can get the flashlight on?
Options:
(A) 5
(B) 8
(C) 7
(D) 6
(E) 4
column3: If you break the batteries into 3 groups: Two groups of 3 and one group of 2. By doing this you guarantee that one of the groups has 2 working batteries. Both of the groups of 3 have 3 possible combinations of 2 batteries and the group of 2 only has 1 combination. So, 3 + 3 + 1 = 7 tries at most to find two working batteries.

column3: If new speed is a⁄b of original speed, then usual time × (b⁄a - 1) = change in time\n∴ usual time × (4⁄3 - 1) = 1⁄3\n⇒ usual time = 1⁄3 × 3 = 1 hr

column3: Total # of codes possible is 3*3*3 = 27. column3:

Remaining work = 3/5 * 10/3 = 2 days.

column3:

column1:
X can finish a work in 18 days. Y can finish the same work in 15 days. Yworked for 5 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?

(A) 12
(B) 5
(C) 6
(D) 8
(E) 9
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/18
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/15
Work done by Y in 5 days = 5/15 = 1/3
Remaining work = 1 – 1/3 = 2/3
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (2/3) / (1/18) = 12

column3: The total of seven numbers = 7X15 = 105\nThe total of first 3 and last 3 numbers is = 3 X 14+3 X 19 = 99\nSo, the middle number is (105 - 99 ) = 6

column1:
A tyre has two punctures. The first puncture along would have made the tyre flat in 9 minutes and the second alone would have done it in 6 minutes. If air leaks out at a constant rate, how long does it take both the punctures together to make it flat?
Options:
(A) 1 1⁄2 minutes
(B) 3 1⁄2 minutes
(C) 3 3⁄5 minutes
(D) 4 1⁄4 minutes
(E) None of these
column3: 1 minute’s work of both the punctures = (1⁄9 + 1⁄6) = 5⁄18\nSo, both the punctures will make the tyre flat in 18⁄5 = 33⁄5 min.

column1:
There are seven thieves. They stole diamonds from a diamond merchant and ran away. While running, night sets in and they decide to rest in the jungle.
When everybody was sleeping, two of them woke up and decided to divide the diamonds equally among themselves. But when they divided the diamonds equally, one diamond is left.
So they woke up the 3rd thief and tried to divide the diamonds equally again but still one diamond was left. Then they woke up the 4th thief to divide the diamonds equally again, and again one diamond was left. This happened with the 5th and 6th thief – one diamond was still left.
Finally, they woke up the 7th thief and this time the diamonds were divided equally.
How many diamonds did they steal in total?
Options:
(A) 1961
(B) 1981
(C) 1991
(D) 1971
(E) None of the above
column3: We need a number that is a multiple of 7 that will give a remainder of 1 when divided by 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. The least common multiple of these numbers is 60. So, we need a multiple of 7 that is 1 greater than a multiple of 60.

column1:
The distance between West-Town to East-Town is 15 kilometers. Two birds start flying simultaneously towards one another, the first leaving from West-Town at a speed of 2 kilometers per minute and the second bird, leaving from East-Town, at a speed of 1 kilometers per minute. What will be the distance, in kilometers, between the meeting point and West-Town?
Options:
(A) 3.
(B) 7.
(C) 10.
(D) 12.
(E) 15.
column3: Time taken by the birds to meet = 15/(2 + 1) = 5 mins\nDistance traveled by the bird traveling from West-Town = 2 * 5 = 10

column3: 10 books can be rearranged in 10! ways consider the two books taken as a pair then number of favourable ways of getting these two books together is 9! 2!\nRequired probability = 1/5

column1:
If 80 percent of the test takers taking an old paper and pencil GMAT exam answered the first question on a given math section correctly, and 75 percent of the test takers answered the second question correctly, and 5 percent of the test takers answered neither question correctly, what percent answered both correctly?
Options:
(A) 60 %
(B) 65 %
(C) 70%
(D) 75%
(E) 80%
column3: {Total} = {First correctly} + {Second correctly} - {Both correctly} + {Neither correctly}\n100 = 80 + 75 - {Both correctly} + 5\n{Both correctly} = 60.

column3: The integer should be divisible by: 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12, that is 2^2, 5, 2*3, 7, 2^3, 3^2, 2*5, 11, 3*2^2. The least common multiple of these integers is the product of 11, 7, 5, 3^2 and 2^3. Then, M/11 is (11 * 7 * 5 * 3^2 * 2^3)/11 = 7*5*9*8 = 2520.

column1:
A person spends 1/3rd of the money with him on clothes, 1/5th of the remaining on food and 1/4th of the remaining on travel. Now, he is left with Rs 300. How much did he have with him in the beginning?
Options:
(A) s 200
(B) s 750
(C) s 300
(D) s 450
(E) s 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 300 = 750

column1:
Suzy has a lot of skeins of yarn, she has blue, yellow, and red yarn. She has twice as much blue yarn as yellow yarn, and she has twice as much yellow yarn as she has red yarn. If she has X skeins of yarn, how many of the skeins are red, in terms of X?
Options:
(A) X/8
(B) X/7
(C) X/6
(D) X/5
(E) X/4
column3:
Since the total number of skeins is X, then X = Blue + Yellow + Red
Because there are twice as many Blue as Yellow, then Blue = 2*Yellow
Thus X = 2*Yellow + Yellow + Red, which simplifies to X = 3*Yellow + Red
Because there are twice as many Yellow as Red, then Yellow = 2*Red
Thus X = 3*(2*Red) + Red, which simplifies to X = 7*Red
Therefore Red = X/7

If a certain coin is flipped, the probability that the coin will land heads is 1/2. If the coin is flipped 5 times, what is the probability that it will land heads up on the first 3 flips and not on the last 2 flips?
Options:
(A) 3/5
(B) 1/2
(C) 1/5
(D) 1/8
(E) 1/32
column3:
On the first three flips, you must get heads. Whats the probability of getting heads ? Its 1/2
So for the first three flips, your probability is (1/2)^3 = 1/8
Now for the last two, you want to get tails only. Whats the prob of getting tails ? Well, its the same as prob of getting a heads, namely, 1/2
For the last two flips, your probability is (1/2)^2 = 1/4
So your overall probability for the event in question is 1/8*1/4 = 1/32

A girl is organizing her jellybean collection in which each color has its own row. In each row, there are as many jellybeans as the number of jellybean colors. Her little brother chops each jellybean into the same number of peices as the number of jellybean colors. If the final number of jellybean pieces is m, then:
Options:
(A) m is a perfect square
(B) m is an odd number
(C) m is an even number
(D) m is a perfect cube.
(E) None
column3: For example, if there were 4 jellybean colors, the girl would have made a 4x4 arrangement. The boy chopped up each jellybean into 4, the number of pieces would be (4*4)*4 = 64 pieces, which is a cube of 4.

column1:
189. The inside dimensions of a rectangular wooden box
are 12 inches by 14 inches by 16 inches. A cylindrical
canister is to be placed inside the box so that it stands
upright when the closed box rests on one of its six
faces. Of all such canisters that could be used, what is
the radius, in inches, of the one that has maximum
volume?
Options:
(A)  3
(B)  4
(C)  5
(D)  6
(E)  7
column3: Since the radius is squared, the biggest volume cylinder will have the biggest possible radius. To achieve that, let the smaller dimension of the rectangular box be the height. So, it will have 16x14width x length. The biggest cylinder must fit both dimensions, so it must have at most a diameter of 14, so the radius will be 7.

column1:
P and Q can complete a work in 20 days and 12 days respectively. P alone started the work and Q joined him after 4 days till the completion of the work. How long did the work last?
Options:
(A) 5 days
(B) 9 days
(C) 30 days
(D) 20 days
(E) 10 days
column3:
Work done by P in 1 day = 1/20
Work done by Q in 1 day = 1/12
Work done by P in 4 days = 4 × (1/20) = 1/5
Remaining work = 1 – 1/5 = 4/5
Work done by P and Q in 1 day = 1/20 + 1/12 = 8/60 = 2/15
Number of days P and Q take to complete the remaining work = (4/5) / (2/15) = 6
Total days = 4 + 6 = 10

Two trains are traveling on parallel tracks in the same direction. The faster train travels at 130 miles per hour, while the slower train travels at 100 miles per hour. At 2 o’clock the faster train is 20 miles behind the slower one. How far apart are the two trains at 5 o'clock?
Options:
(A) 60 miles
(B) 70 miles
(C) 90 miles
(D) 120 miles
(E) 400 miles
column3:
Answer = B. 70 miles
Relational speed = 130 - 100 = 30 miles per hour
In 3 hours, difference = 30 * 3 = 90 miles
Fast train trailing 20 miles, so effective difference = 90 - 20 = 70 miles

column3:
1 man's 1 day work = 1/100

1 woman's 1 day work = 1/100
1 woman alone can complete the work in 100 days.

column3: |35 - 6n| represents the distance between 35 and 6n on the number line. Now, the distance will be minimized when 6n, which is multiple of 6, is closest to 35. Multiple of 6 which is closest to 35 is 36 (for n = 6), so the least distance is 1: |35 - 36| = 1.

Three grades of milk are 1 percent, 5 percent and 3 percent fat by volume. If x gallons of the 1 percent grade, y gallons of the 5 percent grade, and z gallons of the 3 percent grade are mixed to give x+y+z gallons of a 7 percent grade, what is x in terms of y and z?
Options:

(B) (y +z)  / 4
(C) 2y + 3z
(D) 3y + z
(E) 3y + 4.5z
column3: Based on the given information, the following equation could be dervied: 1% * x + 5% * y + 3% * z = 7% * (x+y+z)\nThen use algebra to figure out 6%*x = -2%*y - 4%*z. Thus, 3x = -1y - 2z.

column1:
A telephone company needs to create a set of 3-digit area codes. The company is entitled to use only digits 2, 4 and 3, which can be repeated. If the product of the digits in the area code must be even, how many different codes can be created?
Options:
(A) 20
(B) 26
(C) 24
(D) 22
(E) 30
column3: Total # of codes possible is 3*3*3 = 27. Oit of those 27 codes only the product of 333 will be odd, the remaining 26 will have either 2 or 4 in them, which ensures that their product will be even. Therefore the number of codes where the product of the digits is even = (total) - (restriction) = 27 - 1 = 26.

How many digits are in the number 50^8 × 8^3 × 11?
Options:
(A) 18
(B) 20
(C) 19
(D) 22
(E) 17
column3:
Whenever you are asked to find the number of digits, try to bring the number in multiples of 10. This way, we can wasily calculate the umber of 0's through the powers of 10
50^8 × 8^3 × 11 = (5^2*2)^8*2^9*11 = 5^16*2^17*11 = 2*11*10^16 = 22*10^16
Hence we would have 16 trailing 0's and the three digits from 22
Total digits = 2 + 16 = 18

The average of 13 numbers is 59. Average of the first 7 of them is 57 and that of the last 7 is 61. Find the 8th number?
Options:
(A) 59
(B) 83
(C) 45
(D) 53
(E) 64
column3:
Sum of all the 13 numbers = 13 * 59 = 767
Sum of the first 7 of them = 7 * 57 = 399
Sum of the last 7 of them = 7 * 61 = 427
So, the 8th number = 427 + 399 - 767 = 59.

column3:
Let number of boys = x

189. The inside dimensions of a rectangular wooden box
are 8 inches by 10 inches by 12 inches. A cylindrical
canister is to be placed inside the box so that it stands
upright when the closed box rests on one of its six
faces. Of all such canisters that could be used, what is

volume?
Options:
(A)  3
(B)  4
(C)  5
(D)  6
(E)  8
column3: Since the radius is squared, the biggest volume cylinder will have the biggest possible radius. To achieve that, let the smaller dimension of the rectangular box be the height. So, it will have 12x10 width x length. The biggest cylinder must fit both dimensions, so it must have at most a diameter of 10, so the radius will be 5.

column3: We need a number that is a multiple of 7 that will give a remainder of 1 when divided by 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. The least common multiple of these numbers is 60. So, we need a multiple of 7 that is 1 greater than a multiple of 60.

Three digit numbers = 3 x 3 x 2 x 1 = 18
Total = 34

column1:
From a Group of 10 People, Including George and Nina, 3 people are to be selected at random to work on a certain project. What is the probability that 3 people selected will include George but not Nina
Options:
(A) 5/56
(B) 9/56
(C) 28/120
(D) 21/56
(E) 25/56
column3:
Number of ways of selecting 3 people out of 10 people = 10C3
In the three members George will always be there in the team. At this step we have vacancy for 2 more members and 9 members are available. Lina cannot be there in the team. So 2 members have to be selected and the number of available members = 9 - Nina = 8
Number of ways to form a 3 member team that includes George and excludes Nina = 8C2
Probability = 8C2/10C3 = 28/120

column1:
The average of seven numbers is 22. The average of first three numbers is 14 and the average of last three numbers is 19. What is the middle number?
Options:
(A) 27
(B) 55
(C) 31
(D) 34
(E) 35
column3: The total of seven numbers = 7X22 = 154\nThe total of first 3 and last 3 numbers is = 3 X 14+3 X 19 = 99\nSo, the middle number is (154 - 99 ) = 55

column1:
Anitha had 80 currency notes in all, some of which are of Rs 95 denomination and the remaining of Rs 45 denomination. The total amount of all these currency notes was Rs. 4000. How much amount (in Rs) did she have in the denomination of Rs 45?
Options:
(A) 3500
(B) 72
(C) 2000
(D) 3000
(E) 4000
column3: Let the number of 45-rupee notes = x\nThen, the number of 95-rupee notes = (80 – x)\n45x + 95(80 – x) = 4000 or x + 2(80 – x) = 95 or x = 72.

column1:
The average of seven numbers is 21. The average of first three numbers is 19 and the average of last three numbers is 23. What is the middle number?

(C) 18
(D) 19
(E) 21
column3: The total of seven numbers = 7X21 = 147\nThe total of first 3 and last 3 numbers is = 3 X 19+3 X 23 = 126\nSo, the middle number is (147 - 126 ) = 21

column3: Work done by the waste pipe in 1 minute = 1/15 - (1/20 + 1/24) = - 1/40\nVolume of 1/40 part = 3 gallons\\nVolume of whole = 3 * 40 = 120 gallons.

column1:
A password for a computer is six digits from 0 and 9. The six digit number is a prime number. What is the approximate probability that the last digit is a 3?
Options:
(A) 1/4
(B) 1/6
(C) 1/10
(D) 1/20
(E) 1/50
column3: If the last digit is 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8, the number is even and therefore not prime. If the last digit is 5, the number is divisible by 5 and therefore not prime. The only possibilities are 1, 3, 7, and 9. So the probability is approximately 1/4 (answer A). We say approximately because there is a certain degree of randomness in the distribution of prime numbers.

column1:
If 17m − n = p, then which of the following represents the average (arithmetic mean) of m, n, and p, in terms of m?
Options:
(A) 2m −1
(B) 4m
(C) 6m
(D) m/5
(E) 6m/5
column3:
17m - n = p
Add n to both sides:
17m = n + p
Add m to both sides:
18m = n + p + m
Now, divide both sides by 3
6m = (n + p + m)/3 = the average of n, p, and m

column1:
Two trains are traveling on parallel tracks in the same direction. The faster train travels at 120 miles per hour, while the slower train travels at 100 miles per hour. At 2 o’clock the faster train is 10 miles behind the slower one. How far apart are the two trains at 6 o'clock?
Options:
(A) 60 miles
(B) 80 miles
(C) 110 miles
(D) 120 miles
(E) 400 miles
column3:
Answer = C. 110 miles
Relational speed = 120 - 100 = 20 miles per hour
In 4 hours, difference = 20 * 4 = 120 miles
Fast train trailing 10 miles, so effective difference = 120 - 10 = 110 miles

A man, a woman and a boy can complete a job in 3, 4 and 12 days respectively. How many boys must assist 1 man and 1 woman to complete the job in 1/4 of a day?
Options:
(A) 41
(B) 43
(C) 31
(D) 84
(E) 81
column3:
(1 man + 1 woman)’s 1 day work = 1/3 + 1/4 = 7/12
Work done by 1 man and 1 women in 1/4 day = ((7/12) x (1/4)) = 7/48
Remaining work = 1 - 7/48 = 41/48
Work done by 1 boy in 1/4 day = ((1/12) x (1/4)) = 1/48
Therefore, Number of boys required = ((41/48) x 48) = 41

column1:
The average age of a class of 14 students is 10 yrs. if the teacher's age is also included, the average increases by one year. Find the age of the teacher
Options:
(A) 30 Years
(B) 31 Years
(C) 32 Years
(D) 34 Years
(E) 25 Years
column3:
Total age of students is 14X10 = 140 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 15X (10+1) = 165
So, Teacher's age is 165-140 = 25 Yrs
There is a shortcut for these type of problems
Teacher's age is 10+(15X1) = 25 Years

Options:
(A) 220 meters
(B) 360 meters
(C) 420 meters
(D) 600 meters
(E) Cannot be determined
column3:
Speed of the train in metres/sec = 72000/3600 = 20
Distance travelled by train to cross the platform = 30 * 20 = 600 = Length of train + Length of platform
Distance travelled by train to cross the man = 19 * 20 = 380 = Length of train
Length of platform = 600 - 380 = 220

column1:
A bag contains 3 red and 2 black ball. Another bag contains 4 red and 5 black balls. A ball is drawn from the first bag and is placed in the second. A ball is then drawn from the second. What is the probability that this draw of red ball is due to the drawing of red ball from the first bag ?
Options:
(A) 3/5
(B) 2/5
(C) 4/25
(D) 3/10
(E) 15/23
column3:
Probability of getting red ball from bag1 and then red from bag 2 = 3/5*5/10 = 15/50
Probability of getting black ball from bag1 and then red from bag 2 = 2/5*4/10 = 8/50
Now comes the condition, hence apply conditional probability:
P(Red)/ P(Red + Black)
(15/50)/(15/50+8/50) = 15/50 /23/50 = 15/23.

column1:
In a certain animal population, for each of the first 3 months of life, the probability that an animal will die during that month is 1/10. For a group of 400 newborn members of the population, approximately how many would be expected to survive the first 3 months of life?
Options:
(A) 240
(B) 246
(C) 252
(D) 292
(E) 298
column3:
Number of newborns that can die in first month = 1/10 * 400 = 40
Survived = 360
Number of newborns that can die in second month = 1/10 * 360 = 36
Survived = 324
Number of newborns that can die in third month = 1/10 * 324 = 32
Survived = 292

column3:

In a garden, carrots are planted in rows. In each row there are as many carrots as the number of rows in the garden. If each plant attracts as many bunnies as the number of carrots in each row and if the total number of bunnies is n, then :
Options:
(A) n is a perfect square
(B) n is an odd number
(C) n is an even number
(D) n is a perfect cube
(E) none
column3: For example, if there were 4 carrot rows, the garden would have a 4x4 arrangement. If each carrot attracts 4 bunnies, the number of bunnies would be (4*4)*4 = 64 pieces, which is a cube of 4.

Two persons A and B can complete a piece of work in 30 days and 45 days respectively. If they work together, what part of the work will be completed in 2 days?
Options:
(A) 2/5
(B) 1/6
(C) 1/4
(D) 1/9
(E) 2/6
column3:
A's one day's work = 1/30
B's one day's work = 1/45
(A + B)'s one day's work = 1/30 + 1/45 = 1/18
The part of the work completed in 2 days = 2 (1/18) = 1/9.

Options:
(A) 2
(B) 4
(C) 6
(D) 8
(E) 10
column3:
8! = 40320
E. 4^10 = 1048576 (40320/1048576) - this is not a factor of 8!
D. 4^8 = 65536 (40320/65536) - this is not a factor of 8!
C. 4^6 = 4096 (40320/4096) - this is not a factor of 8!
B. 4^4 = 256 (40320/256) - this is not a factor of 8!
A. 4^2 = 16 (40320/16) - this is a factor of 8!

P can do a work in 24 days. Q can do the samework in 9 days & R can do the same work in 12 days. Q & R start the work and leave after 3 days. P finishes the remaining work in how many days.
Options:
(A) 8
(B) 10
(C) 14
(D) 16
(E) 19
column3:
Work done by P in 1 day = 1/24
Work done by Q in 1 day = 1/9
Work done by R in 1 day = 1/12
Work done by Q and R in 1 day = 1/9 + 1/12 = 7/36
Work done by Q and R in 3 days = 3×7/36 = 7/12
Remaining work = 1 – 7/12 = 5/12
Number of days in which P can finish the remaining work = (5/12) / (1/24) = 10

A person spends 1/3rd of the money with him on clothes, 1/5th of the remaining on food and 1/4th of the remaining on travel. Now, he is left with Rs 400. How much did he have with him in the beginning?
Options:
(A) s 200
(B) s 1000
(C) s 300
(D) s 450
(E) s 550
column3:
Suppose the amount in the beginning was Rs ’x’
Money spent on clothes = Rs 1x/3 Balance = Rs 2x/3
Money spent on food = 1/5 of 2x/3 = Rs 2x/15
Balance = 2x/3 - 2x/15 = Rs 8x/15
Money spent on travel = 1/4 of 8x/15 = Rs 2x/15 = 8x/15 - 2x/15 = 6x/15 = Rs2x/5
Therefore 2x/5 = 400 = 1000

column3: Circumference C is given by\nC = 2πr = 2π*8 = 16 π cm

column1:
Eddy and Freddy start simultaneously from city A and they travel to City B and City C respectively. Eddy takes 3 hours and Freddy takes 4 hours to complete the journey. If the distance between City A and City B is 600 kms and City A and City C is 460 kms. What is the ratio of their average speed of travel? (Eddy: Freddy)
Options:
(A) 8/3
(B) 3/8
(C) 8/5
(D) 5/8
(E) 40/23
column3:
Distance traveled by Eddy = 600 km
Time taken by Eddy = 3 hours
Average speed of Eddy = 600/3 = 200 km/hour
Distance traveled by Freddy = 460 km
Time taken by Freddy = 4 hours
Average speed of Freddy = 460/4 = 115 km/hour
Ratio of average speed of Eddy to Freddy = 200/115 = 40/23

column1:
If a 3-digit integer is selected at random from the integers 700 through 899, inclusive, what is the probability that the second digit is one greater then the first digit, and the third digit is one greater than the second digit?
Options:
(A)  2/225
(B)  2/200
(C)  8/700
(D)  1/50
(E)  1/200
column3:
Hundreds digit can be 7 or 8
If the hundreds digit is 7, then the tens digit has to be 8 and the units digit has to be 9
If the hundreds digit is 8, then the tens digit has to be 9 and the units digit has to be 10
A digit has to fall between 0 and 9, so 10 cannot be a digit
The number is 789
Total numbers between 700 and 899 = (899-700)+1 = 200
Probability = 1/200

column1:
Jamie's friend Bob is having a party, but Jamie forgot and went to dinner with her friend Emily instead. Bob's party starts in half an hour. Bob lives 30 km away from Jamie, and the restaurant Jamie and Emily are at is three times as far away from Bob's house as Jamie's house is.
How fast would Jamie have to drive in order to get to Bob's party on time?
Options:
(A) 30 km/h
(B) 45 km/h
(C) 60 km/h
(D) 75 km/h
(E) 90 km/h
column3: Distance between Bob's house and Jamie's restaurant: 30 x 3 = 90 km\nRate of speed to get to Bob's house in an hour: 90 x 1 = 90 km/h\nRate of speed to get to Bob's house in half an hour: 90/2 = 45 km/h

(C) 50, 60 kmph
(D) 45, 55 kmph

column3: Speed of the boat in still water = (100+112)/2 = 106 kmph. Speed of the stream = (100-112)/2 = 6 kmph

column1:
The average age of a class of 32 students is 16 yrs. if the teacher's age is also included, the average increases by one year. Find the age of the teacher
Options:
(A) 49 Years
(B) 51 Years
(C) 53 Years
(D) 54 Years
(E) 55 Years
column3:
Total age of students is 32X16 = 512 Years
Total age inclusive of teacher = 33X (16+1) = 561
So, Teacher's age is 561-512 = 49 Yrs
There is a shortcut for these type of problems
Teacher's age is 16+(33X1) = 49 Years

column3: Part filled by (A + B + C) in 3 minutes = 3(1/30 + 1/20 + 1/10) = 11/20\nPart filled by C in 3 minutes = 3/10\nRequired ratio = 3/10 * 20/11 = 6/11

column3: Work done by the waste pipe in 1 minute = 1/15 - (1/20 + 1/24) = - 1/40\nVolume of 1/40 part = 3 gallons\\nVolume of whole = 3 * 40 = 120 gallons.

column1:
Which of the following is not divisible by 8?

(A) 10032
(B) 21192
(C) 47816
(D) 91232
(E) 72034
column3:
Divisibility rule of 8: Last three digits of the number should be divisible by 8
Option A: 10032, last three digits = 032. Divisible by 8
Option B: 21192, last three digits = 192. Divisible by 8
Option C: 47816, last three digits = 816. Divisible by 8
Option D: 91232, last three digits = 232. Divisible by 8
Option E: 72034, last three digits = 034. Not divisible by 8. Hence 72034 is not divisible by 8

In a division sum, the remainder is 4 and the divisor is 2 times the quotient and is obtained by adding 2 to the thrice of the remainder. The dividend is:
Options:
(A) 72
(B) 90
(C) 100
(D) 110
(E) 120
column3:
Diver = (4*3)+2 = 14
2* Quotient = 14
Quotient = 7
Dividend = (Divisor * Quotient) + Remainder
Dividend = (14 * 7) + 2 = 100

column3:
Speed of the train in metres/sec = 72000/3600 = 20

Length of platform = 600 - 300 = 300

column3:
Number of newborns that can die in first month = 1/10 * 500 = 50
Survived = 450
Number of newborns that can die in second month = 1/10 * 450 = 45
Survived = 405
Number of newborns that can die in third month = 1/10 * 405 = 40
Survived = 365

A car traveled from San Diego to San Francisco at an average speed of 45 miles per hour. If the journey back took twice as long, what was the average speed of the trip?

(B) 32.
(C) 36.
(D) 42.
(E) 44.
column3:
Let the time taken be = x
One way distance = 45x
Total distance traveled = 2 * 45x = 90x
Total time taken = x + 2x = 3x
Average speed = 90x/3x = 30

column3: 7a/30 tells us that a is a factor of 30, which has 2, 3, and 5 as its prime factors. Each of them is distinct. Moreover, all multiples of 30 less than 200 can be derived by multiplying these prime factors alone. Thus, number of different prime factors is 3.

If x is an odd integer, which of the following is an odd integer?
Options:

(B) x^2
(C) 2x+4x
(D) 1+2x+x^2
(E) 3x-1
column3:
Plug in an odd integer; in this case 3
(2*3)+2 = 8 Even
3^2 = 9 Odd
(2*3)+(4*3) = 6 + 12 = 18 Even
1+(2*3)+3^2 = 1+ 6 + 9 = 16 Even
(3*3)-1 = 9 - 1 = 8 Even

If 1/2 of the air in a tank is removed with each stroke of a vacuum pump, what fraction of the original amount of air has been removed after 6 strokes ?
Options:
(A) 63/64
(B) 7/8
(C) 1/4
(D) 1/8
(E) 1/16
column3:
Left After 1st stroke = 1/2
Left After 2nd stroke = 1/2 * 1/2 = 1/4
Left After 3rd stroke = 1/2 * 1/4 = 1/8
Left After 4th stroke = 1/2 * 1/8 = 1/16
Left After 5th stroke = 1/2 * 1/16 = 1/32
Left After 6th stroke = 1/2 * 1/32 = 1/64
So removed = 1- 1/64 = 63/64

column1:
X can finish a work in 24 days. Y can finish the same work in 16 days. Yworked for 10 days and left the job. how many days does X alone need to finish the remaining work?
Options:

(B) 5
(C) 6
(D) 8
(E) 9
column3:
Work done by X in 1 day = 1/24
Work done by Y in 1 day = 1/16
Work done by Y in 10 days = 10/16 = 5/8
Remaining work = 1 – 5/8 = 3/8
Number of days in which X can finish the remaining work = (3/8) / (1/24) = 9
